text: is toasted soybean flour. It is commonly used in Japanese cuisine.Andoh, Elizabeth. (2012). Washoku: Recipes from the Japanese Home Kitchen, p. 14. Kinako itself is not sweet, but people often add sugar into kinako and coat the mixed-one to wagashi (Japanese sweets), for example Warabimochi. ==History== The use of kinako was recorded during the Yayoi period from 300 BC to 300 AD.Shurtleff, William and Akiko Aoyagi (2009). History of Miso, p. 772. ==References== Category:Japanese food Category:Flour
title: Kinako
